title: Powell bets on a win by Trump and Boris
text:
Powell nominated two major developments - prospects of a truce in the US-China trade war and the growing likelihood of a controlled Brexit - that have shifted risks to the outlook in a positive direction and removed the need for further stimulus.

The twin horsemen of doom that have dominated 2019 have slowed their gallop towards the abyss.

If the so-called "phase one" deal with China announced this month by President Donald Trump is signed and put into place, that could - in Powell's words - "bode well for business confidence and activity over time".

Business confidence, as the latest figures on the US economy show, is the main thing holding growth back. Consumers flush with rising wages and benefiting from strong jobs growth have kept things ticking over.

Second, "while there's still uncertainty as a result of the coming election in Britain . . . . the tail risk of a non-negotiated no-deal Brexit seems to have decreased", Powell said.

"There's plenty of risk left, but the risks do seem to have subsided."

Powell's remarks echo what Reserve Bank of Australia governor Philip Lowe has been saying since he took part in the International Monetary Fund's annual meeting in Washington two weeks ago.

What both Powell and Lowe are saying, in effect, is that a significant measure of the future trajectory of economic growth now rests with key global leaders. Central banks have done what they can.

Advertisement

Chile's decision on Wednesday (Thursday AEDT) to cancel next month's Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) summit has set back hopes that Trump and China's president Xi Jinping would use the forum to sign a starting deal to end their two-year trade war.

But both sides are now scrambling to find an alternative opportunity, according to some reports.

Powell made no reference to the Chile cancellation, suggesting policymakers don't regard it as endangering chances of a potential breakthrough.

With Wall Street equity markets close to records, Powell did nothing to disturb investors on Wednesday (Thursday AEDT) when he pointedly dismissed questions about whether he would return to "normalising" rates next year.

He responded by saying the Fed would only raise rates if inflation began to pick up, and "we don't see that".

"It seems to be settling in below 2 per cent . . . . inflation expectations have moved down and sideways.

"We're not thinking about raising rates right now. What we're really thinking now is that our current stance is appropriate and will remain so."

Powell has given notice that the Fed is done.

The only things that would change that outlook, he indicated, is if economic growth, employment or inflation collapsed.
description: The Fed's mid-cycle adjustment is over and, it would seem, a new normal has been reached.
